document.docTitle: Augiades vespasius subsp. vespasius vespasius (Fabricius 1793, stat. rev., comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of the Neotropical Augiades Hübner, [1819] (Lepidoptera: Hesperiidae)

heading.emphasis:
Augiades vespasius vespasius ( Fabricius, 1793 )
, stat. rev., comb. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs 1E–J , 3D–F , 4B )

(no genus)
vespasius
; Jones, 1785 –1787? [unpublished]. Icones 5 , pl. 86 (d, v).

. Ent. Syst. 3 , p. 334; Indiis, Dom Jones, Jon. Fig. pict. 6. tab. 86, fig. 1.—Weber, 1795.

; Mabille & Boullet, 1919 . Ann. Sc. nat., Zool. , Paris, (10)2 : 244, 245.—Draudt, 1922, in Seitz,

cydana
.—K. Brown & Mielke, 1967. Jour. Lep. Soc. 27 : 158.—Kesselring & Ebert, [1982]. Rev. Nordestina Biol . 2 : 110.—Bridges, 1983. Lep. Hesp. 1 , p. 32, 39; 2 , p. 4; syn .:

. Pesq. agropec. bras. 3 : 60; nom. nud . (ICZN, Art. 12.1.—no description).

(no genus)
epimethea
; Beattie, 1976. Rhop. Direct ., p. 137.

(no genus)
cydana
; Beattie, 1976. Rhop. Direct ., p. 121.

Augiades epimethea
; Garwood et al ., 2009. Butt. South. Amaz ., 2nd ed., p. 275, figs (d, v).—Garwood & Lehman, 2013. Butt. C. Amer. 3, Hesp ., p. 9, fisg (d, v).—Salik et al ., 2014. Shilap Revta. Lepid. 42 (166): 273.

Type material.
Hesperia vespasius
was described based on a figure in volume 6 of the unpublished work known as the “Jones’ Icones ”. As the volumes were rebound, the plate with the figure is now in volume 5 (see Waterhouse 1938 ). Some species described by Fabricius were based only on illustrations, and in such cases, there are no type specimens known (O. Karsholt, com. pess.). Zimsen (1964) in her publication about the type material of Fabricius also did not mention any known syntype . Thus, a male neotype of
Hesperia vespasius
is hereby designated, aiming to establish the correct identity of the species. The chosen neotype specimen has the same morphological characteristics of the specimen illustrated by Jones ( Icones 5, pl. 86), and is deposited at the DZUP with the following labels: / Neotypus / Neotypus
Hesperia vespasius Fabricius, 1793
, Siewert, Lemes, O. Mielke & Casagrande det. 2020/ Linhares—E[spírito] S[anto] [ Brazil ] V-1982 C. Elias leg. / DZ 45.497/.

Phareas epimethea Plötz, 1883
was described based on an unspecified number of specimens from Brazil . The type material of Plötz is deposited at ZMHU and ZSM, however, no syntypes of
P. epimethea
were found in those collections. Aiming to establish the correct identity of the species, one male specimen is hereby designated as the neotype of
Phareas epimethea Plötz, 1883
. The same specimen used as the neotype for
H. vespasius
is chosen to be the neotype for
P. epimethea
, which has the same morphological pattern of the species described by Plötz. The following label will be added: / Neotypus
Phareas epimethea Plötz, 1883
, Siewert, Lemes, O. Mielke & Casagrande det. 2020/.

Lignyostola cydana
Schaus, 1902
was described based on the [holo]type from Petrópolis, [ Rio de Janeiro ], Brazil .
The male holotype is deposited at the USNM with the following labels: / Petropolis , Brazil ./ Collection W. Schaus /
Lignyostola cydana
type Schaus / Type No. 5975 U.S.
N.M./.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Male genitalia of
Augiades species. A
–C.
A. crinisus
(Peru, Madre de Dios, Parque Manu, Patizka, DZ 5.096) in (A) Lateral view of tegumen, saccus, uncus and gnathos and lateral view of valva; (B) Dorsal view of tegumen, uncus and gnathos; and (C) Lateral view of aedeagus. D–F.
A. vespasius vespasius
(Brazil, Rio de Janeiro, Duque de Caxias, Imbariê, DZ 45.925). G–I.
A. vespasius bicolor
(Brazil, Acre, Senador Guiomard, Reserva Catuaba, DZ 45.307).

FIGURE 4. Female genitalia of
Augiades species. A
.
A. crinisus
(Brazil, Espírito Santo, Linhares, DZ 45.974). B.
A. vespasius vespasius
(Brazil. Rio de Janeiro, Duque de Caxias, Imbariê DZ 45.938).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. FW length: males 24–27 mm (n=30) and females 26–28 mm (n=5).
Augiades vespasius vespasius
is distinguished from
A. crinisus
by the absence of hyaline spots on FW in males, although these spots may be present in some females. In some specimens, it is possible to observe the presence of these hyaline spots but never welldeveloped as in
A. crinisus .
The brown color of the marginal area of the wings is lighter in
A. v. vespasius
than in
A. crinisus
. The following combination of genitalic characters differentiates
A. v. vespasius
from
A. crinisus
: uncus thinner than in
A. crinisus
; valva with shortly bifid distal margin; lamella antevaginalis bilobed, rectangular and with smooth margin; lamella postvaginalis sclerotized at median region. Males of
A. v. vespasius
differ from males of
A. v. bicolor
due to the absence of a postdiscal area conspicuously marked in the VHW in the latter. Females of
A. v. vespasius
are distinguished from
A. v. bicolor
by presenting in the VHW a faded yellow postdiscal area with a broad central light brown band, while the latter present a yellow-orange discal and postdiscal areas with remnants of a brown band in the postdiscal area.

Variation. Some specimens have narrow hyaline spots on FW, similar to
A. crinisus
( Fig. 1I–J ).

Distribution.
Augiades vespasius vespasius
occurs in forested areas with records in the Brazilian states of Paraíba , Pernambuco , Alagoas , Bahia , Goiás , Minas Gerais , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , São Paulo , Paraná , and Santa Catarina ( Fig. 5 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Geographic distribution of
Augiades species.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Taxonomic discussion. Plötz (1883) described
Phareas epimethea
, and later the species was transferred to
Lignyostola
by Mabille & Boullet (1919) and to
Augiades
by Evans (1952) , remaining as a valid species until now. Evans (1953) erroneously interpreted
Telemiades nicomedes (Möschler, 1879)
as
Telemiades vespasius ( Fabricius, 1793 )
and his interpretation was followed by several authors (see
Siewert et al. 2020
). The specimen illustrated by Jones (Jones’ Icones 1785–1787?) and which was used for the description of
Hesperia vespasius
does not correspond to any species of
Telemiades
and undoubtedly corresponds to
Augiades
( Fig. 2 ). Thus, we propose a new combination and a new status for
A. vespasius vespasius
, with
P. epimethea
as its junior synonym.

By misinterpretation, Evans (1953) synonymized
Eudamus phlius Plötz, 1881
with
T. vespasius
.
Siewert et al. (2020)
examined the type series of
E. phlius
and corroborated its synonymy with
T. nicomedes
, whose type material was also examined. However, some of the taxa described by Fabricius were based only on Jones’ Icones figures, and in such cases, there are no type specimens known ( Zimsen 1964 ; O. Karsholt, pers. comm.), making the designation of a neotype for
Hesperia vespasius Fabricius, 1793
necessary to establish its identity. It is worth mentioning that Evans (1953) erroneously synonymized
Hesperia curtius Fabricius, 1793
with
Telemiades vespasius ( Fabricius, 1793 )
, but the specimen illustrated by Jones led
Siewert et al. (2021)
to consider that name as a junior synonym of
Nisoniades mimas (Cramer, 1775)
.
